dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, uh, big news from an unexpected corner, I think. Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoft...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, uh, big news from an unexpected corner, I think. Satya Nadella, the C E O of Microsoft...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Satya Nadella, Microsofts CEO, said Wednesday during the Forbes JUST 100 virtual summit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, Microsoft? I thought the article said Apple?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, Microsoft? I thought the article said Apple?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, my bad, yeah, it did, but that's a typo in the source! It's definitely Satya Nadella of Microsoft. He, like, just came out saying now's the time for America to reimagine capitalism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, my bad, yeah, it did, but that's a typo in the source! It's definitely Satya Nadella of Microsoft. He, like, just came out saying now's the time for America to reimagine capitalism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid a global pandemic, months-long protests over racial inequality and a bitterly contested election, the CEO of the worlds second largest public company says now is the time for America to reimagine capitalism. ... Satya Nadella, Microsofts CEO...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's, um, a pretty bold statement, especially from a tech giant CEO, right? Considering everything going on this year – pandemic, protests, the election...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's, um, a pretty bold statement, especially from a tech giant C E O, right? Considering everything going on this year - pandemic, protests, the election...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid a global pandemic, months-long protests over racial inequality and a bitterly contested election, the CEO of the worlds second largest public company says now is the time for America to reimagine capitalism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He said it's fair to have a "referendum on capitalism" right now. And, uh, he's basically saying companies like Microsoft should be measured by the jobs and revenue they create *outside* the company, not just their internal surpluses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He said it's fair to have a referendum on capitalism right now. And, uh, he's basically saying companies like Microsoft should be measured by the jobs and revenue they create outside the company, not just their internal surpluses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its fair, in today in 2020, in the midst of this pandemic, to essentially have a referendum on capitalism, Satya Nadella, Microsofts CEO, said Wednesday... In short, Nadella said, companies like Microsoft should be measured by the number of jobs and revenue created outside of the company and the economic impact they have on the markets where they operate, as opposed to surpluses generated within a company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so it's not just about the bottom line within the company walls, but more about the broader economic impact? That sounds a lot like what they call "stakeholder capitalism," doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so it's not just about the bottom line within the company walls, but more about the broader economic impact? That sounds a lot like what they call stakeholder capitalism, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadellas comments, which he says were inspired by a book published last year by Oxford management studies professor Colin Mayer, follow ongoing calls for business leaders to commit to steering their corporations toward so-called stakeholder capitalism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. He was inspired by this Oxford professor, Colin Mayer. And, you know, the World Economic Forum, the Business Roundtable – they've all been pushing this. Bezos, Dimon, they signed on too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. He was inspired by this Oxford professor, Colin Mayer. And, you know, the World Economic Forum, the Business Roundtable - they've all been pushing this. Bezos, Dimon, they signed on too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadellas comments, which he says were inspired by a book published last year by Oxford management studies professor Colin Mayer... Earlier this year, the World Economic Forum at Davos used the phrase as the theme for its annual event, a move that came after nearly 200 CEOs of large corporations including Amazon's Jeff Bezos and JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon signed new guidelines by the Business Roundtable that specified the role of a corporation was to promote an economy that serves all Americans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but didn't a recent report kinda cast doubt on how committed those companies actually are to that idea? Like, it's easy to say, harder to do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but didn't a recent report kinda cast doubt on how committed those companies actually are to that idea? Like, it's easy to say, harder to do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Good point. But Nadella, he did point to Microsoft's own actions, like their pledge to become carbon neutral by 2022. And LinkedIn's push to address racial inequality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good point. But Nadella, he did point to Microsoft's own actions, like their pledge to become carbon neutral by twenty twenty two. And LinkedIn's push to address racial inequality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030, and highlighted a push by LinkedIn to address racial inequality as initiatives supported by shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, those are tangible steps, I guess. Especially with Microsoft's, like, explosive growth under him, mostly from cloud services during the pandemic. So he's not just, you know, talking the talk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, those are tangible steps, I guess. Especially with Microsoft's, like, explosive growth under him, mostly from cloud services during the pandemic. So he's not just, you know, talking the talk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since Nadella took over as Microsoft CEO in 2013, the company has experienced explosive growth, in large part thanks to a booming cloud services business a sector that has only recorded surging demand during the pandemic as the global workforce was forced to work from home.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And it wasn't just about capitalism. He also touched on the upcoming federal election, which is kinda overshadowed by, uh, concerns about the outcome.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And it wasn't just about capitalism. He also touched on the upcoming federal election, which is kinda overshadowed by, uh, concerns about the outcome.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beyond the pandemic and racial justice issues, Nadella also discussed the upcoming federal election, which has been overshadowed by President Donald Trumps assertions he may not accept its outcome.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? What did he say there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? What did he say there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He really stressed Microsoft's reliance on a strong democracy. He said their global standing as an American tech company comes directly from the "vibrancy of American democracy."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He really stressed Microsoft's reliance on a strong democracy. He said their global standing as an American tech company comes directly from the vibrancy of American democracy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadella emphasized Microsofts reliance on a strong democracy and the need to maintain its institutions. As an American company and tech company our standing in the world, and in the United States, comes because of the vibrancy of the American democracy, Nadella told Andrea Jung, the CEO of Grameen America, who hosted the talk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So connecting the health of the business to the health of democratic institutions. That's a powerful statement, especially right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So connecting the health of the business to the health of democratic institutions. That's a powerful statement, especially right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So therefore any standing of any business, including ours, depends on us building on that strong institution of democracy here and everywhere else.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. It's, um, a pretty holistic view of corporate responsibility, beyond just, like, quarterly earnings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. It's, um, a pretty holistic view of corporate responsibility, beyond just, like, quarterly earnings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. It makes you think about how much bigger the role of a CEO has become.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. It makes you think about how much bigger the role of a C E O has become.
